The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.

Let $G, G^{\'prime}$ be monoids with corresponding unit elements $e$ and $e^{\'prime}$. A monoid homomorphism $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\'prime}$ is a map $\varphi$ from $G$ to $G^{\'prime}$ such that (i) $\varphi(e)=e^{\'prime}$, (ii) $\varphi(a b)=\varphi(a) \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Does the concept of a/an Symmetric Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Monoid Homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Monoid Homomorphism involves a mapping between two monoids that preserves the monoid structure, specifically the identity element and the operation of the monoid. This concept is defined independently of the specific type of monoid involved, and it applies generally to any monoids, whether they are groups, rings, or any other structures with a monoid operation.

The Symmetric Group, on the other hand, is a specific type of group that consists of all the permutations of a finite set. It is a particular example of a group, and thus also a monoid, but it represents just one specific kind of group among many possible groups and monoids.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of a Monoid Homomorphism do not rely on the concept of the Symmetric Group. A Monoid Homomorphism can be discussed and understood entirely without reference to Symmetric Groups. The concept of a Monoid Homomorphism is applicable to any monoids, not just those that are also groups or specifically symmetric groups.
